{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11649,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio californicus, commonly known as California ragwort, prefers to be watered moderately during the growing season, which is primarily spring and early summer. It is important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as this plant is drought tolerant. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough to keep the soil from completely drying out. Overwatering should be avoided, as it can lead to diseases. Use well-draining soil to help manage moisture levels effectively."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio californicus thrives in full sun locations where it can receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is well adapted to sunny, dry climates and can tolerate intense sun exposure. While it can grow in partial sun, providing plenty of direct sunlight helps ensure a more robust and floriferous plant. If growing indoors or in less optimal conditions, ensure it is positioned near a bright window. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduce blooming efficiency."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio californicus involves removing dead or damaged stems and any spent flowers to encourage healthy growth and a more attractive appearance. The best time to prune is in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This plant doesn’t require heavy pruning, but trimming back about one-third of the oldest growth annually can help maintain its shape and size. Regular pruning can also improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of disease. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant tissues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California ragwort","description":"Senecio californicus is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common name California ragwort....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["California ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Senecio californicus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11450,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salsola tragus, commonly known as Russian thistle, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. It thrives in arid and semi-arid regions, and excessive watering can lead to root rot. It is best to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During its growing season, water the plant sparingly, ensuring that the top few inches of soil are dry before watering again. In its dormant season, reduce watering significantly. Overwatering should be avoided, as this can harm the plant and disrupt its growth balance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salsola tragus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It grows best in open and sunny environments, making it suitable for areas that receive ample sunlight throughout the day. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and weak stems. If growing outdoors, select a location that gets maximum sun exposure. In areas where sunlight is less intense, you may need to strategically position the plant to capture optimal light. This sunlight requirement is crucial for its healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salsola tragus is typically not necessary as it is often managed for containment rather than aesthetic appeal. However, if pruning is desired to control its size or prevent it from becoming invasive, it is best done during late fall or early spring before the plant starts its active growth cycle. Use sharp pruning shears to trim back any overgrown or dead branches, making clean cuts near the base of the stem. Avoid pruning more than one-third of the plant at a time to prevent stress. Regular pruning can help manage its spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Prickly Russian Thistle","description":"Kali tragus is a species of flowering plant in the family Amaranthaceae. It is known by various common names such as prickly Russian thistle, windwitch, or common saltwort. It is widely known simply as tumbleweed because in many regions of the United States, it is the most common and most conspicuous species of tumbleweed. Informally, it also is known as \"salsola\", which was its generic name until fairly recently.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Prickly Russian Thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Salsola tragus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Arid"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11049,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viola tricolor, commonly known as wild pansy, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. During its growing season, water regularly to maintain the soil's moisture, especially in hot and dry periods. However, make sure the soil drains well to prevent water accumulation, which can lead to root rot. During cooler weather or when the plant is dormant, reduce watering frequency. It's important to monitor the soil moisture by feeling the top layer; if it feels dry to the touch, it's time to water. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases, opting for ground-level watering instead."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola tricolor thrives in locations that receive full sun to partial shade. Ideally, aim for at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes healthy growth and vibrant blooms. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from wilting or becoming scorched. The plant is quite adaptable and can tolerate less light, but this might result in fewer flowers. If grown indoors, place the viola near a bright window with several hours of sunlight. Adjust its location seasonally to ensure it receives adequate light year-round."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola tricolor involves regular deadheading to encourage blooming and prevent the plant from going to seed too quickly. Remove spent flowers by pinching or cutting the stem just above the nearest leaf. This practice not only extends the flowering period but also promotes bushier growth. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, you can trim it back by up to one-third to maintain a compact shape. In late fall, cut the plant back to tidy its appearance and prepare it for the dormant season. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and minimize the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wild Pansy","description":"Viola tricolor, also known as Johnny Jump up (though this name is also applied to similar species such as the yellow pansy), heartsease, heart's ease, heart's delight, tickle-my-fancy, Jack-jump-up-and-kiss-me, come-and-cuddle-me, three faces in a hood, or love-in-idleness, is a common European wild flower, growing as an annual or short-lived perennial.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Wild Pansy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Viola tricolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11149,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Alliaria petiolata, commonly known as garlic mustard, is a hardy plant typically found in the wild and does not require frequent watering once established outdoors. If you're growing garlic mustard in a garden setting, it prefers evenly moist soil but is drought-tolerant once mature. Overwatering should be avoided as it prefers soil that is not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In their natural habitat, they thrive best with natural rainfall, and additional watering might only be necessary in periods of prolonged drought."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alliaria petiolata thrives in part shade to full shade environments, which aligns with its native habit of growing under tree canopies and forest understories. It can tolerate some sun exposure but generally does better and grows more vigorously in shaded areas. When planting in gardens, aim for locations that simulate this dappled light environment. Too much direct sunlight, especially in hotter climates, could stress the plant, leading to wilting or stunted growth. Thus, providing filtered light or placing it in naturally shaded sections will yield the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Alliaria petiolata is mostly about controlling its spread, as it is an invasive species in many areas. Regularly remove any flowering stems before they set seed to prevent spreading. If controlling growth in a garden, cut back plants before they mature in late spring to early summer when they are in flower. All plant parts should be disposed of responsibly, as seeds can remain viable in the soil for several years. While it doesn't require shaping or aesthetic pruning, management trimming will help prevent it from dominating native plants."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"garlic mustard","description":"Alliaria petiolata is a biennial flowering plant in the Mustard family, Brassicaceae. It is native to Europe, western and central Asia, and northwestern Africa, from Morocco, Iberia and the British Isles, north to northern Scandinavia, and east to northern Pakistan and western China (Xinjiang).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["garlic mustard"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Alliaria petiolata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11245,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sanicula laciniata, commonly known as Coastal Black Snakeroot, thrives in environments that mimic its natural habitat of coastal and woodland regions. It benefits from regular watering but does not need excessive moisture, preferring well-drained soil. You should aim to keep the soil moderately moist, especially during its growing season in spring and early summer. However, allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent waterlogging and root rot. During the dormant season in winter, reduce watering significantly, just giving enough moisture to prevent the soil from completely drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sanicula laciniata grows best in partial to full shade conditions, reflecting its native habitat in shaded woodland areas. While it can tolerate some sunlight, especially morning sun, it should be protected from harsh, direct afternoon sunlight that can scorch its foliage and stress the plant. Providing dappled or filtered sunlight through canopy cover is ideal. If planted in a garden setting, consider placing it under trees or near taller structures that provide natural shade. This setup will ensure the plant retains its lush, green foliage without suffering from overheating or drought stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sanicula laciniata is largely a matter of removing dead or damaged foliage to maintain its appearance and health. It does not require extensive pruning; however, cutting back the plant after flowering can encourage a tidier look and potentially stimulate some new growth. Deadhead the spent flowers if you want to limit its seeding and spread, but leave sufficient foliage to support the plant's growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts, and aim to prune during its growth season for best results. Avoid pruning in winter when the plant is dormant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"laceleaf sanicle","description":"Sanicula laciniata is a flowering plant species of in the family Apiaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10746,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cornus sericea, commonly known as Red Osier Dogwood, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. During the growing season, water the plant regularly to maintain damp soil, especially in dry spells. It's important not to let the soil dry out completely as this can stress the plant. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant. A layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool. Ensure the soil is not waterlogged, as soggy conditions can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cornus sericea thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and vibrant stem coloration. However, it can tolerate some shade, although this may result in less intense red coloring of the stems. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. Planting in a location with morning sun and afternoon shade can be beneficial for the health and appearance of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cornus sericea is essential to maintain its vibrant red stems and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove older, less vibrant stems down to the base to allow room for new shoots. You can also thin out crowded areas to enhance air circulation and sunlight penetration. Annually rejuvenating by cutting back a third of the oldest stems can promote healthier, more vibrant growth. Avoid pruning during fall as it may stimulate new growth susceptible to frost damage."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"red osier dogwood","description":"Cornus sericea, the red osier or red-osier dogwood, is a species of flowering plant in the family Cornaceae, native to much of North America. It has sometimes been considered a synonym of the Asian species Cornus alba. Other names include red brush, red willow, redstem dogwood, redtwig dogwood, red-rood, American dogwood, creek dogwood, and western dogwood.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["red osier dogwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cornus sericea"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10648,"attracts":["Insects (for trapping)"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drosera intermedia, also known as the oblong-leaved sundew, thrives in consistently moist to wet conditions. It is best to use distilled, rain, or deionized water to avoid mineral build-up, which can harm the plant. Keep the pot in a tray of water to ensure the soil remains constantly moist, especially during the growing season. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this can stress the plant. During the hottest parts of the day in summer, some shade may be beneficial to avoid leaf burn, particularly if the plant is not acclimated to intense sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Drosera intermedia is minimal, mainly involving the removal of dead or dying leaves or inflorescences to encourage new growth and prevent fungal infections. Use sterilized scissors or tweezers to gently trim away any brown or decayed parts. Be careful not to damage the dewy traps as they are crucial for the plant's nutrition. Pruning can be done throughout the growing season, but pay particular attention during late dormancy to prepare the plant for new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spoonleaf sundew","description":"Drosera intermedia, commonly known as the oblong-leaved sundew, spoonleaf sundew, or spatulate leaved sundew, is an insectivorous plant species belonging to the sundew genus. It is a temperate or tropical species native to Europe, southeastern Canada, the eastern half of the United States, Cuba and northern South America.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["spoonleaf sundew"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Drosera intermedia"],"soil":["Acidic","Peaty","Wet"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11950,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rumex occidentalis, commonly known as western dock, prefers consistently moist soil conditions, but it is important to avoid waterlogging. During the hotter months, increase the frequency of watering to compensate for increased evaporation. However, be cautious of letting the plant's roots sit in standing water, which can lead to root rot. A well-draining soil mix can help maintain the right balance of moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rumex occidentalis grows best in full sun to partial shade conditions. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and ensure healthy foliage. Adjust the plant's location according to seasonal sunlight changes to maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rumex occidentalis involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to promote healthy growth and improve its overall appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12046,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Alcea rosea, commonly known as hollyhock, prefers well-drained soil and benefits from regular watering to maintain evenly moist soil, especially during dry spells. However, be cautious not to overwater, as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. A good practice is to water deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Early morning is the best time to water to allow any excess moisture on the leaves to evaporate, minimizing the risk of fungal diseases. Mulching around the base can help conserve moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alcea rosea thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. Planting hollyhocks in a location where they receive morning sunlight is ideal, as it helps dry the dew on leaves and reduces the risk of rust disease. In regions with extremely hot afternoons, some light afternoon shade might prevent wilting, though these plants generally tolerate heat well. Inadequate sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so ensure they have sufficient exposure for a robust display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Alcea rosea involves cutting back spent flowers to encourage more blooms and maintain plant health. After the flowers have faded, snip off the flower stalks down to the first set of leaves. This not only tidies up the plant but also redirects energy to other parts, potentially resulting in more flowering. At the end of the growing season, cut the entire plant down to near ground level to tidy up your garden and reduce the risk of diseases overwintering in the remnants. Removing dead or damaged leaves throughout the season can also help maintain plant vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Hollyhock","description":"Alcea rosea (common hollyhock) is an ornamental plant in the Malvaceae family. It was imported into Europe from southwestern China during, or possibly before, the 15th century. William Turner, a herbalist of the time, gave it the name \"holyoke\" from which the English name derives.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Asia","Europe"],"other_name":["Hollyhock"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Alcea rosea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid direct sunlight, as it could dry out the substrate or container holding the fungus, impacting its growth. Instead, mimic the dappled or diffuse light conditions found under forest canopies, allowing this species to thrive in naturally subdued lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning considerations are not applicable to Hypholoma fasciculare as it is a fungus rather than a plant. Fungi like Sulphur Tuft do not require pruning like traditional plants. If you notice unwanted growth on your premises, it may be best to remove the substrate material or relocate the fungus to a controlled environment for observation rather than altering the fungus itself."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"Sulphur Tuft","description":"Hypholoma fasciculare, commonly known as the sulphur tuft, sulfur tuft or clustered woodlover, is a common woodland mushroom, often in evidence when hardly any other mushrooms are to be found. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10446,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Schlumbergera truncata, commonly known as the Thanksgiving cactus, thrives with regular but moderate watering. It is crucial to let the top inch of soil dry out completely between watering sessions to prevent root rot. During the flowering period, typically in late fall or early winter, maintain slightly more frequent watering, but reduce it after blooming. In comparison to other cacti, Schlumbergera prefers more humidity and moisture, so consider misting in drier climates. Always ensure the pot has drainage holes to avoid waterlogged conditions which can be detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Schlumbergera truncata prefers bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, can scorch the plant's delicate segmented leaves. An ideal location is near a north or east-facing window where it can enjoy filtered light. If the plant becomes leggy or pale, it might be a sign of insufficient light. Conversely, brown spots may indicate too much sun exposure. During summer, you might place it outdoors in a shaded spot, but be sure to bring the plant inside before the temperatures drop in autumn to encourage its bloom in time for the holidays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning the Schlumbergera truncata is not only beneficial for health but also encourages bushier growth. The best time to prune is post-bloom, usually in late winter or early spring. Simply use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to cut back each segment at the joint. Focus on removing any segments that appear damaged or excessively leggy. Prune sparingly to maintain its natural shape. The removed segments can be used for propagation, as they root easily in soil. Regular pruning keeps the plant tidy and promotes abundant blooms during the next flowering cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Crab Cactus","description":"Schlumbergera truncata, the false Christmas cactus, is a species of plant in the Cactaceae family. It is endemic to a small area of the coastal mountains of south-eastern Brazil where its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist forests. It is the parent or one of the parents of the houseplants called Christmas cactus or Thanksgiving cactus, among other names.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil"],"other_name":["Crab Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Schlumbergera truncata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11348,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rumex conglomeratus, commonly known as clustered dock, prefers moist environments, so it is crucial to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Regular watering is necessary, especially during dry spells to prevent the plant from wilting. In garden settings, ensure a good drainage system to avoid standing water that could lead to root rot. If grown in containers, it's recommended to water when the top inch of soil feels dry. Adjust watering frequency according to seasonal and climatic changes, providing more in the warmer months and less during cooler, dormant periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rumex conglomeratus thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, ensure the plant receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can benefit the plant by preventing leaf scorch. While it can tolerate a range of light conditions, too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced vigor. Monitor the plant for signs of excessive shade such as slow growth or pale foliage, and adjust its position in the garden accordingly to achieve the right balance of sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rumex conglomeratus primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to maintain plant health and appearance. It’s advisable to prune in early spring before new growth begins or in autumn after the growing season. Regular pruning helps prevent the plant from becoming too leggy and encourages fuller growth. Also, trimming the flower stalks before seed set can prevent self-seeding and uncontrolled spreading, as this plant can become quite invasive. Use clean and sharp gardening shears to make precise cuts close to the base of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Clustered Dock","description":"Rumex conglomeratus, known as clustered dock and sharp dock, is a plant of the family Polygonaceae. An annual or biennial plant growing up to 100 cm high. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11650,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Berberis pinnata, a drought-tolerant shrub, prefers infrequent watering once established. During the initial growing period, keep the soil consistently moist but ensure it's well-draining to prevent root rot. Water deeply every 1-2 weeks, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Reduce frequency in autumn and winter when the plant enters dormancy. Mulching can help retain moisture and maintain a stable root environment. Adjust watering based on rainfall and humidity, observing the plant's foliage for signs of under or overwatering, such as wilting or yellowing leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Berberis pinnata thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and the best foliage color, provide at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch, while in cooler regions, more sun exposure can be beneficial. If planted in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers and berries. Position the shrub where it receives morning sun and some protection from the intense afternoon rays. Consistent sunlight helps maintain its dense, compact form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Berberis pinnata annually to maintain shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches. Then, thin out crowded areas to improve airflow and light penetration within the shrub. You can also shape the plant by cutting back overly long branches. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts just above a leaf node. Be cautious of the plant's thorns while pruning, and wear gloves to protect your hands."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California barberry","description":"Mahonia pinnata (syn. Berberis pinnata) is a species of shrub in the barberry family. Common names include California barberry, wavyleaf barberry, and shinyleaf mahonia. It is similar to the Oregon-grape (Mahonia aquifolium), and is sometimes called the California Oregon-grape.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["California barberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Berberis pinnata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11150,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sorbus aucuparia, commonly known as the rowan or mountain ash, is quite tolerant of varying moisture levels but performs best in moderately moist conditions. It requires regular watering during its first few years to establish a strong root system. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of the soil to dry out before rewatering. Once established, the tree is fairly drought-tolerant, but during prolonged dry spells, supplementary watering may be necessary to keep the tree healthy. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sorbus aucuparia thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers a location where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes optimal flowering and berry production. In areas with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from intense heat. While the tree can tolerate partial shade, prolonged lack of sunlight may result in reduced fruiting and less vibrant foliage. Therefore, select a planting site that provides ample sunlight for the majority of the day to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sorbus aucuparia is essential for maintaining its shape and removing any dead or diseased wood. Prune the tree in late winter or early spring when it is still dormant. Focus on removing any crossing or rubbing branches, and thin out crowded areas to increase air circulation within the canopy. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can negatively impact the tree's natural form and flowering potential. Light trimming to shape the tree and remove any suckers or water sprouts can help encourage healthy growth and enhance its ornamental appeal."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European mountain ash","description":"Sorbus aucuparia, commonly called rowan and mountain-ash, is a species of deciduous tree or shrub in the rose family. It is a highly variable species, and botanists have used different definitions of the species to include or exclude trees native to certain areas; a recent definition includes trees native to most of Europe and parts of Asia, as well as northern Africa. The range extends from Madeira and Iceland to Russia and northern China. Unlike many...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["European mountain ash"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Fire Blight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Sorbus aucuparia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If growing clover in garden beds, simply trim back any overgrown or leggy stems to promote tidiness and healthier growth. Be careful not to remove too much foliage at once, as this can stress the plant. Ensure that your pruning shears are clean to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"white clover","description":"Trifolium repens, the white clover (also known as Dutch clover, Ladino clover, or Ladino), is a herbaceous perennial plant in the bean family Fabaceae (Previously referred to as Leguminosae). After establishment, watering should be deep and infrequent, mimicking natural rainfall patterns, which encourages deep root growth. Positioning the plant where it can receive morning sun and light afternoon shade can help balance its need for light and protection from heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Amelanchier utahensis should be done annually during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Light thinning helps increase air circulation within the tree, improving overall health. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant and reduce blooms in the following season. This maintenance ensures the fungus can mature fully and healthily. Always sanitize tools before and after to avoid spreading contamination."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"yellow-tipped coral fungus","description":"Ramaria formosa, commonly known as the beautiful clavaria, handsome clavaria, yellow-tipped- or pink coral fungus, is a coral fungus found in Asia, Europe and North America. In late fall or early spring, trim back any remaining dead or yellowed stems to make way for new growth. It prefers consistent moisture levels, particularly during its active growing period in fall and winter. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to avoid waterlogging the roots. During the summer dormancy period, reduce watering significantly, as the plant naturally withstands drier conditions during this time. Ensure the plant is not sitting in water as it can lead to root rot. Adjust watering frequency depending on the local climate and indoor humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polypodium californicum prefers a semi-shaded environment, thriving in dappled sunlight or bright, indirect light. Natural habitats include shaded woodland areas, so replicating similar conditions will benefit the plant. Direct sunlight can cause the fronds to scorch, so it’s best placed away from intense afternoon sun. If growing indoors, an east or north-facing window is ideal, providing gentle, filtered light throughout the day. In a garden setting, it does well under the canopy of larger trees or shrubs. Ensure that the plant receives adequate light to maintain its vibrant frond color and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polypodium californicum is a straightforward task. This fern primarily requires the removal of dead or damaged fronds to maintain its aesthetic appeal and encourage healthy new growth. Trim back any browning or dried fronds at their base, especially at the end of its active cycle, during the late winter. Avoid excessive pruning of healthy fronds, as this can stress the plant. Clearing out dead foliage also helps enhance air circulation and reduces the risk of pest infestations. Regular maintenance pruning keeps the fern looking tidy and can promote a more vigorous growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Polypody","description":"Polypodium californicum is a species of fern known by the common name California polypody.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["California Polypody"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores","Rhizome Division"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Polypodium californicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is crucial to keep the soil consistently damp, particularly during its active growth period in spring and early summer. The plant naturally thrives in habitats near water bodies, so it's adapted to high moisture levels. Avoid letting the soil dry out between waterings, and try to emulate its natural habitat by ensuring good drainage while maintaining soil moisture. During dry spells, additional watering will help in maintaining its vibrant growth. Regular monitoring is recommended to ensure optimal moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Montia chamissoi prefers partial shade to full sun, reflecting its native environment often under taller vegetation or near bodies of water. Ideally, provide dappled sunlight or partial shade, especially during the hottest parts of the day, to prevent wilting or scorching of its delicate leaves. In cooler climates, it can tolerate more sun, while in hotter areas, additional shade can be beneficial to protect it from excessive heat. Essentially, balanced light exposure is optimal, allowing the plant to photosynthesize efficiently without suffering from extreme conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Montia chamissoi is generally minimal, given its natural growth habit. However, removing dead or damaged foliage can improve air circulation around the plant and maintain a healthy appearance. If the plant becomes too dense, thinning out some of the older growth can prevent overcrowding and encourage fresh growth. Pruning is best done in late summer after the flowering season, using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to minimize damage. This process not only aids in aesthetic maintenance but also helps keep the plant vigorous and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"toadlily","description":"Montia chamissoi is a species of flowering plant in the Montiaceae family known by the common names of water minerslettuce, water montia, Indian lettuce, and toad lily. It is native to much of western North America from Alaska to the southwestern and central United States and also in British Columbia. It grows in moist to wet soils in a variety of habitat types, such as meadows, wetlands, plains, and montanes (Kershaw et al., 1998). It is...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["toadlily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Montia chamissoi"],"soil":["Wet","Moist","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11453,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus edulis, commonly known as the piñon pine, is a drought-tolerant species that requires very little water once established. Water young trees deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to encourage deep root growth. Mature piñon pines generally only need supplemental watering during extended dry periods. Be cautious not to overwater as this can lead to root rot and other moisture-related issues. In well-draining soil, ensure that each watering is thorough, reaching several inches of depth to promote healthy root development and resilience."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus edulis thrives in full sun environments. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to grow well. The piñon pine is adapted to thrive in open areas with ample sunlight, which is essential for its growth and production of cones. Ensure the planting site is unobstructed by larger trees or structures that could block sunlight. In less than optimal light conditions, the tree may become spindly and produce fewer cones, thereby reducing its overall vigor and health. Thus, choosing a location with sufficient sun exposure is critical for its success."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning piñon pines should be minimal and primarily to maintain the tree's shape or remove dead or diseased branches. It is best done in late winter to early spring before new growth begins, to minimize stress on the tree. Ensure that all cuts are clean and made close to the trunk or to a side branch. Avoid excessive pruning, as piñon pines are slow-growing and may not recover quickly. Removing more than 25% of the tree's foliage at one time is not recommended as it can weaken the plant and make it vulnerable to pests and diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Colorado Pinyon","description":"Pinus edulis, the Colorado pinyon, two-needle piñon, pinyon pine, or simply piñon, is a pine in the pinyon pine group whose ancestor was a member of the Madro-Tertiary Geoflora (a group of drought resistant trees) and is native to the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Colorado Pinyon"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus edulis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10851,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Juglans californica, or California walnut, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered deeply but infrequently. During the growing season, water the tree every 7 to 10 days to ensure the soil remains moist but not soggy. Reduce watering in the late fall and winter months, as the tree enters a dormant period and requires less moisture. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot and other water-related issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"California walnut trees thrive in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. Sunlight is crucial for the tree's photosynthetic process and helps it produce energy for growth and nut production. Ensure the tree is planted in an area with ample sunlight exposure. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight might lead to reduced vigor and lower nut yields."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Juglans californica during late winter to early spring when the tree is still dormant to shape the tree and remove any dead or diseased branches. Pruning helps increase airflow and light penetration, promoting healthier growth. Avoid heavy pruning as walnuts are sensitive and can be stressed by extensive cuts. It's important to make clean cuts to prevent disease. Thin the tree to maintain an open canopy, which can improve fruit production and overall tree health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Southern California Walnut","description":"Juglans californica, the California black walnut, also called the California walnut, or the Southern California black walnut, is a large shrub or small tree (up to 30 feet tall) of the walnut family, Juglandaceae, endemic to California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","USA"],"other_name":["Southern California Walnut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Juglans californica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10945,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eriogonum heracleoides, commonly known as Wyeth buckwheat, requires minimal watering once established. It is a drought-tolerant plant, adapted to dry environments, so overwatering can harm its health. In the first growing season, water regularly to help the plant establish a strong root system. Thereafter, water sparingly, particularly during extremely dry spells. Ensure the soil has excellent drainage to prevent root rot caused by standing water. A thorough watering every 2-3 weeks during dry periods is typically sufficient."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eriogonum heracleoides thrives in full sunlight conditions, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. It is well-suited to open landscapes where it can soak in all the sunlight necessary. Although it can endure some light shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. Planting in a sunny spot helps replicate its natural habitat conditions, ensuring the plant remains healthy and blossoms prolifically."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eriogonum heracleoides is generally minimal, primarily focusing on maintaining plant health and appearance. After the flowering season, which typically occurs in late spring to summer, you can deadhead spent blooms to promote a tidier appearance and, occasionally, to encourage a second flush of flowers. In late winter or early spring, remove any dead or damaged foliage to encourage new growth. Avoid severe pruning as this can stress the plant; gentle trimming is usually all that is needed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"parsnipflower buckwheat","description":"Eriogonum heracleoides (common names; parsnipflower buckwheat, whorled buckwheat, and Wyeth buckwheat) is a plant that has many flowering clusters which are usually cream coloured, or off-white. It can usually be found in rocky areas, such as sagebrush deserts and Ponderosa pine forests. Parsnipflower buckwheat is in the genus Eriogonum and the family Polygonaceae, which is a family of plants known as the \"knotweed family\". It inhabits much of the western part of the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western United States"],"other_name":["parsnipflower buckwheat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Eriogonum heracleoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10749,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Garrya elliptica should be watered regularly during the first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system. Once established, it is fairly drought-resistant and needs only occasional watering, particularly during prolonged dry spells. Be mindful of overwatering, especially in poorly drained soils, as this can lead to root rot. During its winter dormancy, reduce watering to prevent waterlogged conditions. Always ensure the soil is well-draining and allow the top layer to dry out before re-watering to maintain the plant’s health and vigor."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Garrya elliptica thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a location where it can receive morning sun and some afternoon shade, particularly in hotter climates, to prevent scorching. In cooler regions, full sun is ideal to promote better flowering. The shrub is versatile and can tolerate a wide range of light conditions, but too much shade can result in poor flowering and leggy growth. Ensure it has at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to develop its cascading catkins properly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Garrya elliptica is best done after it has finished flowering, typically in late winter to early spring. This timing allows you to shape the plant without sacrificing the next season's blooms. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation within the shrub. Light pruning can also help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Be careful not to over-prune, as this can reduce the number of flowers the plant produces the following year. Regular trimming can help manage the size, especially if grown in formal gardens."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Coast silk tassel","description":"Garrya elliptica, the coast silk-tassel, silk tassel bush or wavyleaf silktassel, is a species of flowering plant in the family Garryaceae, native to the coastal ranges of California and southern Oregon. It is an erect, bushy, evergreen shrub reaching a height of 2–5 m (7–16 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["USA"],"other_name":["Coast silk tassel"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Garrya elliptica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11652,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassula tillaea, also known as mossy stonecrop, is a drought-tolerant succulent and does not require frequent watering. It thrives in well-draining soil and should only be watered when the soil is completely dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot and harm the plant. During the growing season (spring and summer), water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out fully between watering. In the winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant's growth slows down and it enters a period of dormancy. Always ensure good drainage to prevent water from sitting at the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula tillaea prefers bright, indirect sunlight, which mimics its natural habitat conditions. Ensure it has space to expand, as it will develop a large canopy over time."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juglans nigra is essential for maintaining its structure and health. Prune during the dormant season, ideally late fall to early winter, to minimize sap loss and reduce the risk of disease spread. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote airflow and light penetration. Thin out crowded areas and shape the tree to a balanced form. Avoid heavy pruning in one season; instead, spread pruning over several years to lessen stress on the tree. Regularly check for crossing branches and remove them to prevent damage as they grow."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern black walnut","description":"Juglans nigra, the eastern black walnut, is a species of deciduous tree in the walnut family, Juglandaceae, native to eastern North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10550,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus strobus, or eastern white pine, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering once established. In its early stages or if planted in a particularly dry season, water the pine deeply once a week. Ensure the soil is moist but not waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Once the tree matures, natural rainfall is usually sufficient to meet its water needs, unless there is an extended period of drought. Always allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to avoid overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus strobus thrives best in full sun, ideally receiving at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. When planting, ensure the site has enough sun exposure, and avoid overly shaded areas to prevent inadequate development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus strobus should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove only the dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain tree health. Pinching or cutting back new growth can control size and form, but be cautious not to over-prune, as this pine can look lopsided if too much is removed. Due to their natural shape, these trees require minimal pruning once established, primarily to ensure the tree's structural integrity and remove hazardous branches."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern white pine","description":"Pinus strobus, commonly denominated the eastern white pine, northern white pine, white pine, Weymouth pine (British), and soft pine is a large pine native to eastern North America. When grown in gardens, it should be watered regularly to mimic its natural habitat, especially during dry spells. Ensure that the plant is not left to dry out completely, as this could hinder its growth and overall health. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex pseudocyperus prefers partial to full shade, reflecting its natural habitat along shaded wetlands and riversides. If grown indoors, placing it near a north or east-facing window can provide the light intensity it needs. Ensuring the plant is not exposed to harsh afternoon sun can help maintain its lush, green appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex pseudocyperus involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and health. Regularly tidying up the plant encourages robust and healthy growth throughout the season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cyperus Sedge","description":"Carex pseudocyperus is a species of flowering plant in the sedge family known by the common name cyperus sedge or hop sedge. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11748,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lilium humboldtii, commonly known as Humboldt's lily, requires well-drained soil and should be watered deeply but infrequently. It is vital to allow the topsoil to dry out moderately between waterings to prevent root rot. Overwatering is more damaging than occasional underwatering. During its growing period in spring and early summer, increase the frequency of watering, but ensure that the soil remains not overly saturated. Taper off watering as the plant enters dormancy in late summer. Using mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering needed."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Humboldt's lily thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, especially morning sun. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from the intense midday sun which can scorch the leaves. Site this lily in a location where it can receive reliable sunlight, but ensure it's shielded from extreme heat. If growing in an area with intense sun, consider planting it alongside taller plants or structures that can provide dappled sunlight or sufficient shade during the hottest part of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lilium humboldtii involves cutting back the stem only after the foliage has completely yellowed and died back in the fall. This dying foliage process provides the bulb with nutrients for the next blooming cycle. Removing the dead stalks close to ground level after the plant has naturally died back helps maintain plant health and appearance. Additionally, any diseased or damaged leaves should be pruned throughout the blooming season to prevent the spread of disease and encourage healthy growth, taking care not to remove too many leaves at once."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Humboldt's Lily","description":"Lilium humboldtii (Humboldt's lily) is a species of lily native to the US state of California and the Mexican state of Baja California. It is named after naturalist and explorer Alexander von Humboldt. It is native to the South High Cascade Range, High Sierra Nevada, south Outer South Coast Ranges, and the Santa Monica Mountains and others in Southern California, growing at elevations from 600 metres (2,000 ft) to 1,200 metres (3,900 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Mexico"],"other_name":["Humboldt's Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lilium humboldtii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular pruning helps prevent leggy growth and keeps the plant looking tidy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common St. John's Wort","description":"Hypericum perforatum, known as perforate St John's-wort, common Saint John's wort and St John's wort, is a flowering plant in the family Hypericaceae. Avoid cutting back too hard as it may negatively impact flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"marsh cinquefoil","description":"Comarum palustre (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10854,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lemna minor, commonly known as duckweed, thrives in standing or slow-moving water bodies such as ponds and aquariums. It is crucial to keep the plant in water at all times, as it absorbs nutrients directly from the water. Regular changing or filtering of water is important to maintain the right nutrient level and prevent eutrophication, which can endanger the plant due to excessive algae growth. Generally, duckweed doesn’t require additional watering unless it is grown in controlled environments like a container or aquarium that isn’t naturally replenished."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lemna minor thrives in environments with medium to strong indirect sunlight. Ideally, it should receive approximately 10-12 hours of light daily. While it can survive in lower light conditions, growth will slow down significantly. Direct sunlight can be too harsh for duckweed, particularly if the water temperature rises too high, causing potential stress or damage. So, if kept indoors, position the plant in a well-lit area near a window but avoid direct afternoon sunlight, which can be too intense."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lemna minor involves the routine removal of excess growth to prevent overcrowding, which can deplete oxygen levels and hinder the growth of other aquatic life. The plant multiplies quickly, so regular thinning is necessary. This can be done by simply skimming excess plants from the water surface with a net or by hand. Regular removal helps maintain a balanced ecosystem, encouraging a healthy growth environment for both the duckweed and surrounding aquatic organisms."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Duckweed","description":"Lemna minor, the common duckweed or lesser duckweed, is an aquatic freshwater plant of the genus Lemna. They belong to the family of Lemnaceae, which is monophyletic to the Araceae family. L. minor is used as animal fodder, bioremediator, for wastewater nutrient recovery and other applications.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Common Duckweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Lemna minor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Silty"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11655,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arctostaphylos pungens, commonly known as pointleaf manzanita, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in well-drained soil. It requires minimal watering once established. During the initial growing season, it is important to water the plant regularly to help develop a strong root system. After that, it can be watered sparingly, typically every two weeks during dry periods. Over-watering should be avoided, as this can lead to root rot. It is important to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to mimic its native dry environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arctostaphylos pungens thrives in full sunlight, preferring a location that receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. In its natural habitat, this plant is found in open, sunny areas, and mimicking these conditions will ensure optimal growth and health. While it can tolerate some light shade, too much shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. It is best suited for regions where it can receive hot, dry sun, as this will help maintain its characteristic glossy leaves and vibrant appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Arctostaphylos pungens is generally minimal and should be done to maintain shape and health. It is best to prune after the flowering period, removing any dead or diseased branches. Lightly cut back any leggy or wayward growth to promote a more compact form. Be careful not to cut into the older wood, as this can inhibit the plant's ability to regenerate. Manzanita's bark is sensitive, so take care not to damage it while pruning. For encouraging denser growth, trimming the tips of the branches can be beneficial."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pointleaf manzanita","description":"Arctostaphylos pungens, with the common name pointleaf manzanita, is a species of manzanita. It is native to the Southwestern United States and to northern and central Mexico, where it grows in chaparral and woodland habitats, and on desert ridges. Arctostaphylos pungens can be seen growing at Tent Rocks National Monument in New Mexico at an elevation of about 6000 feet.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["pointleaf manzanita"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Arctostaphylos pungens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10450,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Wisteria frutescens, commonly known as American wisteria, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in spring and early summer. Water the plant deeply once a week to encourage deep root growth, ensuring the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. During dry periods, you may need to water more frequently. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Always allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Wisteria frutescens thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal blooming. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade will result in fewer flowers. Planting in a sunny, southern or western exposure will yield the best flowering results. If grown in partial shade, it may develop more foliage than blooms. Ensure the location provides good air circulation to prevent fungal diseases, which can be more prevalent in shaded areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Wisteria frutescens is essential to manage its vigorous growth and encourage better blooming. It should be pruned twice a year, once in late winter while the plant is dormant and once in summer after flowering. In winter, cut back the previous year's growth to two to four buds from the main stem. In summer, trim the long, whippy shoots back to about six inches from the main stem to maintain shape and size. Regular pruning will help control its spread and enhance flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American wisteria","description":"Wisteria frutescens, commonly known as American wisteria, is a woody, deciduous, perennial climbing vine, one of various wisterias of the Fabaceae family. It is native to the wet forests and stream banks of the southeastern United States, with a range stretching from the states of Virginia to Texas (Northeast Texas Piney Woods) and extending southeast through Florida, also north to Iowa, Michigan, and New York.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American wisteria"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Wisteria frutescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11154,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Robinia pseudoacacia, or black locust, is a relatively drought-tolerant plant once established. During the initial growing period, it requires regular watering to help establish a strong root system. Water the plant deeply once a week, ensuring that the soil is moist but not waterlogged. Once established, reduce watering frequency as the plant can handle dry conditions well. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During dry, hot spells, an occasional deep watering will help keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Robinia pseudoacacia thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can also tolerate partial shade, but too much shade may lead to poor flowering and stunted growth. Ideally, provide it with a spot that receives direct morning sunlight, encouraging a robust structure and vibrant blooms. In shaded areas, the plant may become lanky and more susceptible to pests and diseases. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch, but overall, prioritize ample sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Robinia pseudoacacia is best performed in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Begin by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote overall plant health. Thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and light penetration through the canopy. Pruning will also help maintain the desired shape and size of the tree, as it can grow quite tall. Be cautious of thorns and wear protective gloves while pruning. Avoid excessive pruning, as it can stimulate excessive shoot growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"black locust","description":"Robinia pseudoacacia, commonly known in its native territory as black locust, is a medium-sized deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States, but it has been widely planted and naturalized elsewhere in temperate North America, Europe, Southern Africa and Asia and is considered an invasive species in some areas. Another common name is false acacia, a literal translation of the specific name (pseudo meaning fake or false and acacia referring to the genus of plants with...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["black locust"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Leaf miners","Borers"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Robinia pseudoacacia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11054,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Valerianella locusta, commonly known as lamb's lettuce or corn salad, prefers consistently moist soil. Water it regularly to keep the soil slightly damp but not waterlogged. It is important to avoid letting the soil dry out completely between watering sessions. However, take care not to overwater, as excess moisture can lead to root rot. During hot or dry spells, you may need to water more frequently to maintain moisture levels. Mulching can also help retain soil moisture and provide the plant with stable growing conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Valerianella locusta thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. This plant can tolerate some shade, especially in warmer climates, where it might benefit from protection against intense midday sun. However, for optimal growth and leaf production, providing it with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day is recommended. In areas with very high temperatures, partial shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent the leaves from wilting and ensure steady growth throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Valerianella locusta is generally not required, but you can enhance growth by harvesting the leaves regularly. As this plant grows low to the ground and forms a rosette of leaves, picking the outer leaves first encourages the plant to produce more foliage. Once the plant starts to bolt and produce flowers, leaf production generally ceases, so harvest frequently before this stage. Timely harvesting helps maintain plant vigor and leaf quality, ensuring a continuous supply of tender, fresh leaves for your salads."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common cornsalad","description":"Valerianella locusta is a small annual plant that is eaten as a leaf vegetable. It has a characteristic nutty flavor, dark green color, and soft texture, and is popularly served as salad greens. Common names include corn salad, common cornsalad, lamb's lettuce, mâche (/mɑːʃ/), fetticus, feldsalat, nut lettuce, field salad, and rapunzel. In restaurants that feature French cooking, it may be called doucette or raiponce, as an alternative to mâche, by which it is best known....","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["common cornsalad"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Valerianella locusta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to keep the soil slightly damp, but avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In the winter, reduce watering when the plant is dormant. Ensure good drainage and consider using mulch to help retain moisture while preventing the soil from becoming waterlogged."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lilium parvum thrives in partial to full sunlight. It can tolerate full sun, but partial shade conditions are ideal, especially if they provide some protection from the harsh afternoon sun. In hotter climates, morning sunlight with afternoon shade works best to prevent overheating and to keep the soil moisture more stable. For optimal growth, ensure that the plant receives at least four to six hours of sunlight daily. Providing the right balance of light is crucial for healthy blooms and foliage growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lilium parvum involves removing spent flowers to encourage more blooms and reduce energy wastage in seed production. Once the flowering season is over, cut back the stems to the base after they have turned yellow and died back; this will help prepare the plant for the next growth cycle. Avoid cutting back green stems and foliage as they are essential for photosynthesis and building energy reserves in the bulbs. Regularly remove any dead or damaged leaves to maintain plant health and promote better air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sierra Tiger Lily","description":"Lilium parvum is a species of lily known by the common names Sierra tiger lily and alpine lily. It is native to the mountains of the western United States, primarily the Sierra Nevada of California but also with additional populations in northwestern Nevada and southwestern Oregon. The plant grows in high altitude forests, sending up flowering stalks during the summer months.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Sierra Tiger Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Botrytis"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Lilium parvum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, it is important to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Always adjust your watering schedule based on the climate and the specific conditions of your home or garden."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cordyline australis thrives in full sun to partial shade. However, in hotter, more intense climates, providing it with partial shade during the hottest parts of the day is beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. When grown indoors, place the plant near a bright, sunny window where it can receive plenty of indirect light. If the plant is not getting enough light, its growth may become leggy, and its leaves may lose some of their color vibrancy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cordyline australis involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and encourage healthy growth. Cut back brown or yellowing leaves near their base, and snip off any flower stalks after they bloom, if desired. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts and wear gloves to protect against the leaf edges, which can be sharp."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"New Zealand cabbage tree","description":"Cordyline australis, commonly known as the cabbage tree, cabbage-palm or tī kōuka, is a widely branched monocot tree endemic to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["New Zealand cabbage tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Spider mites","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cordyline australis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sand","Slightly acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10855,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tanacetum parthenium, commonly known as feverfew, prefers moderate watering. It is important to let the soil dry out between waterings to prevent waterlogged conditions, as overwatering can lead to root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, increase watering to maintain slight dampness in the soil, but reduce frequency in the fall and winter when the plant’s growth slows down. It is tolerant of drought once established, so err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tanacetum parthenium thrives in full sun, which encourages robust growth and abundant flowering. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, reducing the sunlight may decrease the number of flowers the plant produces. Therefore, for optimal results, plant feverfew in a location where it will receive ample direct sunlight throughout the day, especially during its active growing period in spring and summer."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tanacetum parthenium helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Regular deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can prolong the blooming period. You should also remove any dead or diseased foliage to promote the plant’s health. In the fall, you can cut the plant back more substantially, to about 3 to 5 inches above the ground, to tidy up the plant and prepare it for winter. This hard pruning will encourage strong growth and potentially more flowers in the following spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"feverfew","description":"Tanacetum parthenium, feverfew, is a flowering plant in the daisy family Asteraceae. It is a traditional medicinal herb which is commonly used to prevent migraine headaches, and is also occasionally grown for ornament. It is also commonly seen in the literature by its synonyms, Chrysanthemum parthenium and Pyrethrum parthenium. It is also sometimes referred to as bachelor's buttons or featherfew.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eurasia"],"other_name":["feverfew"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Tanacetum parthenium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is crucial to ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot, as this plant is not tolerant of soggy conditions. Water the plant thoroughly but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings.
