Monitoring soil moisture closely will help maintain the right balance for healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agoseris retrorsa thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. Ideally, the plant should be positioned in an open area where it receives ample morning sunlight, which helps encourage healthy growth and abundant flowering. While the plant is generally adaptable, it benefits from some protection from the harsh midday sun in extremely hot climates. If grown indoors, place the plant in a south or west-facing window where it can enjoy bright light throughout the day. Adequate sunlight is vital for its photosynthesis and overall vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agoseris retrorsa is relatively straightforward and typically involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged leaves to encourage further blooming and maintain the plant's health. Deadheading, or cutting back the flowering stem after blooming, can help prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production, thereby promoting a more robust and prolonged flowering period. It's best to prune these parts before the plant goes to seed in late summer. Regularly check for any diseased plant material and remove it promptly to prevent the spread of any potential diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spearleaf agoseris","description":"Agoseris retrorsa is a North American species of flowering plant in the daisy family known by the common name spearleaf agoseris or spearleaf mountain dandelion.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["spearleaf agoseris"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Agoseris retrorsa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10451,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asclepias californica, or California milkweed, is a drought-tolerant plant that typically requires minimal watering once established. It prefers arid conditions, so it's important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot. During the first growing season, water the plant regularly to establish a strong root system. After that, the plant usually thrives on natural rainfall but may need supplemental watering during prolonged dry spells, especially in hot climates. When watering, it's best to water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asclepias californica thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow well. While it can tolerate some light shading, especially in hotter regions, abundant sunlight promotes more vibrant blooms and a healthier structure. Ideally, this plant should be positioned in a location that receives the most daylight available, such as a south-facing garden bed. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent stress and leaf scorch, ensuring the plant remains vigorous throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias californica is generally minimal but can be helpful to encourage healthy growth. It's best to prune this plant in late winter or very early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing stems to maintain an open structure and improve air circulation. This plant tends to die back to the ground in winter, so cutting it back to just a few inches above the soil can help promote vigorous growth in the spring. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can prolong its blooming period and prevent unwanted self-seeding."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California milkweed","description":"Asclepias californica is a species of milkweed known by the common name California milkweed. It grows throughout lower northern, central and southern California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Blue-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States (California)"],"other_name":["California milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Asclepias californica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11656,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia maculata, commonly known as spotted spurge, requires minimal watering. It is a drought-tolerant plant, so it prefers dry conditions once established. Water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot or garden soil has good drainage. During periods of extended drought or extreme heat, you may need to water more frequently, but generally, rainfall provides sufficient moisture for this resilient plant. Always water at the base to avoid wetting the foliage, as excess moisture on leaves can lead to disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia maculata thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a location with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Under full sun, it grows more compact with vibrant foliage, while in partial shade, it may become more leggy. This adaptability makes it suitable for various conditions, but for optimal growth and to prevent legginess, full sun is ideal. In particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from scorching and preserve plant health. Ensure it's planted in a spot where it receives adequate daily sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia maculata is not typically necessary as it is a low-growing, sprawling plant. However, if you wish to maintain its shape or control its spread, you can trim it back. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruners to cut back any overgrown areas or damaged stems. Wearing gloves is advisable as the plant’s sap can cause skin irritation. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also help prevent seeding and controlling its spread in garden settings. Regular mowing can manage its growth in grass or lawn areas."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Spotted spurge","description":"Euphorbia maculata, variously called spotted spurge or prostrate spurge, the latter name not to be confused with Euphorbia prostrata, is a fast-growing annual plant in the family Euphorbiaceae, native to North America. It is a common garden and lawn weed in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Spotted spurge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia maculata"],"soil":["Dry","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11155,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Morus alba, or the white mulberry, prefers regular watering, especially when young, to establish a strong root system. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Once established, these trees are fairly drought-tolerant and do not require frequent watering, unless during periods of extended drought. It's best to let the top inch of soil dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deeper root development and resilience."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Morus alba thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and fruit production. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure significantly enhances its vigor and yield. In regions with intense heat, afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Ensure that the planting location receives ample sunlight, especially morning sun, which is less intense than the afternoon sun, to support healthy foliage and abundant fruiting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Morus alba should be done during the dormant season in late winter before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health. Thin out overcrowded branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Shape the tree to your desired form by cutting back branches, but avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the tree. Regularly remove any suckers growing from the base to prevent them from sapping energy from the main tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white mulberry","description":"Morus alba, known as white mulberry, is a fast-growing, small to medium-sized mulberry tree which grows to 10–20 m tall. It is generally a short-lived tree with a lifespan comparable to humans, although there are some specimens known to be over 250 years old. The species is native to northern China, and is widely cultivated and naturalized elsewhere (United States, Mexico, Australia, Kyrgyzstan, Argentina, etc.).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China"],"other_name":["white mulberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Bacterial blight","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Morus alba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dry spells or extremely hot weather, you may need to water more often, ensuring that the soil remains slightly moist but not waterlogged."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acacia auriculiformis thrives in full sunlight. It is a hardy tree that can also tolerate partial shade but will perform best with at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Proper sunlight ensures robust growth and optimal blooming. Ensure that the plant is rotated occasionally if light is coming in from one direction to promote even growth and prevent the tree from becoming lopsided."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Acacia auriculiformis should be conducted mainly to maintain shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. Allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions, especially during cooler months. During active growth in spring, provide occasional deep watering to encourage root development, but ensure the soil drains well to prevent root rot. Use a well-draining soil mix to further aid in keeping the plant healthy. Overall, less is more when it comes to watering this hardy desert species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chaenactis fremontii thrives in full sun, reflecting its adaptation to arid desert environments. In shaded conditions, the plant might not flower as profusely and could become leggy as it stretches for sunlight. If grown indoors, ensure it's near a south-facing window where it can receive ample light throughout the day. Providing full light exposure is key to keeping this plant robust and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chaenactis fremontii is generally minimal, focusing on removing dead or diseased growth to maintain overall plant health and appearance. After the flowering period, you can deadhead spent flowers to encourage additional blooms and prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production. This practice also helps maintain the plant's compact shape and prevent legginess. It prefers deep, occasional watering rather than frequent shallow ones. Ideally, the soil around the tree should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. While the tree can tolerate some shade, full sun exposure is best for healthy fruit development and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Mangifera indica is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. It is best to prune mango trees during the early part of the year, just before the spring growth spurt. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches first, as well as branches that cross or grow inwards. Also, thinning the canopy helps improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, which can enhance fruit production. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts, and avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Indian mango","description":"Mangifera indica, commonly known as mango, is a species of flowering plant in the sumac and poison ivy family Anacardiaceae. It is native to the Indian subcontinent, where it is indigenous and cultivated varieties have been introduced to other warm regions of the world. It is a large fruit-tree, capable of a growing to a height and crown width of about 100 feet and trunk circumference of more than twelve feet.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","Bangladesh"],"other_name":["Indian mango"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Mangifera indica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid hard pruning into old wood as it may not regenerate."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California fuchsia","description":"Epilobium canum, also known as California fuchsia or Zauschneria, is a species of willowherb in the evening primrose family (Onagraceae). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10856,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pisum sativum, commonly known as the garden pea, requires regular, consistent watering to thrive, particularly during its growth and flowering phases. Ensuring the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged is crucial. This can be achieved by watering once or twice a week, depending on weather conditions, ensuring the top inch of soil feels damp. During hot and dry periods, more frequent watering may be needed. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. It's also beneficial to water at the base and in the morning to minimize moisture retention on the foliage, which can lead to diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pisum sativum thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimum growth and pod production. Planting in a location where the pea plants will have unfiltered access to sunlight ensures they grow robustly and bear more fruit. In regions where periods of intense heat are possible, partial afternoon shade can help protect the plants from scorching. Insufficient sunlight can lead to spindly growth and reduced yield. Therefore, positioning them in a sunny spot from the outset is crucial for their overall health and productivity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pisum sativum involves removing any dead, diseased, or damaged foliage throughout its growth to maintain the plant’s health and productivity. It's crucial to pinch or cut back the growing tips of vines once they have reached their desired length to encourage bushier growth and increase yield. Regularly harvesting pods when they are mature also acts as a form of pruning by promoting further flowering and pod production. Ensuring clean cuts can prevent plant stress and decrease the risk of disease. Always use sharp, sanitized tools to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Pea","description":"The pea is most commonly the small spherical seed or the seed-pod of the pod fruit Pisum sativum. Each pod contains several peas. Pea pods are botanically fruit, since they contain seeds and developed from the ovary of a (pea) flower. The name is also used to describe other edible seeds from the Fabaceae such as the pigeon pea (Cajanus cajan), the cowpea (Vigna unguiculata), and the seeds from several species of Lathyrus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Middle East","Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Common Pea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pea weevil","Aphids","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Pisum sativum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12053,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Camassia leichtlinii prefers moist soil conditions, especially during its growing and blooming period in spring. Ensure the soil is consistently damp but not waterlogged. It is important to water this plant regularly if rainfall is insufficient, particularly during dry spells. Once the plant has finished flowering and enters dormancy in the summer, you can reduce watering. In fact, too much water during dormancy can lead to bulb rot. During the winter months, natural precipitation is usually sufficient, and additional watering may not be needed if the soil is not dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Camassia leichtlinii thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Full sun ensures they get at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily, which is essential for abundant flowering. However, they can tolerate some shade, particularly in hotter climates, where partial shade might help prevent soil from drying out too quickly and protect plants from the most intense afternoon sun. If planted in too much shade, they may not bloom as well. Therefore, selecting a spot with morning sun and some afternoon protection can be beneficial in warmer regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Little pruning is needed for Camassia leichtlinii. Deadhead the spent flowers to encourage good bulb development and to prevent self-seeding if you don't want a spread of the plants. Wait until the foliage turns yellow and withers before cutting it back, usually in late summer, to allow the plant to store energy in the bulb for the next growing season. Always ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogging the roots, as this plant prefers a semi-arid environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ambrosia acanthicarpa prefers full sun exposure to thrive, as it’s naturally adapted to open and sunny environments. This plant should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, prolonged periods without adequate sunlight may lead to leggy growth and diminished vigor. Additionally, full sunlight exposure helps the plant maintain its compact form and encourages flowering. If growing in a garden, select a location that is not obstructed by larger plants or structures to ensure it gets the required amount of sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Ambrosia acanthicarpa generally aims to reduce its spread and control its size, as it can become invasive in some regions. Regularly check for any dead or damaged stems and remove these to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. Prune the plant back in early spring to maintain its shape and to prevent it from overshadowing nearby plants or spreading too aggressively. When trimming, cut back to a leaf node or main stem to promote denser growth. Always use clean and sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant and spreading potential diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flatspine Bursage","description":"Ambrosia acanthicarpa is a North American species of bristly annual plants in the sunflower family. The plant is common across much of the western United States and in the 3 Prairie Provinces of Canada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Flatspine Bursage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Ambrosia acanthicarpa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When watering, focus on deep, infrequent watering rather than frequent shallow watering to encourage deep root establishment. Reduce the frequency in the fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Glycyrrhiza lepidota thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers full sun conditions for optimal growth and flowering, ideally around 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. When planting, choose a location that provides ample sunlight exposure, taking care to protect the plant from extreme conditions that could stress it."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Glycyrrhiza lepidota primarily involves removing dead or damaged stems and controlling growth to maintain plant health and shape. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Cut back old stems to encourage new, healthy shoots. If the plant becomes too bushy, selectively thin out stems to improve air circulation within the plant. Trim away any spent flowers to prevent unwanted self-seeding, as wild licorice can spread easily. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Licorice","description":"Glycyrrhiza lepidota (American licorice) is a species of Glycyrrhiza (a genus in the pea/bean family, Fabaceae) native to most of North America, from central Canada south through the United States to California, Texas and Virginia, but absent from the southeastern states. It is also sometimes known in the United States as \"wild licorice\", to distinguish it from the related European liquorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra) which is occasionally cultivated.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Wild Licorice"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Glycyrrhiza lepidota"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10555,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vicia cracca, commonly known as tufted vetch, prefers moderate watering conditions. It thrives in moist, well-drained soil, so watering should be adjusted to maintain these conditions without waterlogging the soil, which can lead to root rot. During dry spells or periods of drought, increase watering frequency to ensure the plant receives adequate moisture. Conversely, during rainy periods, reduce watering to prevent oversaturation. Check the soil moisture regularly and water when the top 2-3 inches of soil are dry. It is important to water deeply to encourage strong root growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vicia cracca thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day. In regions with hot summers, it appreciates some afternoon shade to prevent the leaves from scorching. Positioning the plant in an area with morning sunlight and afternoon shade can be beneficial. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced light may limit flower production and result in leggier growth. If growing in a shaded area, ensure that it still receives dappled sunlight throughout the day to maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vicia cracca is generally done to control its growth and prevent it from becoming invasive. It can spread vigorously, so regular trimming helps maintain its size and shape, especially in garden settings. Deadhead the flowers once they start to fade to prevent unwanted self-seeding and to encourage the plant to produce more blooms. Cut back the plant after flowering season or in early spring to promote bushier growth and to remove any dead or damaged stems. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts, which helps prevent diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tufted vetch","description":"Vicia cracca (tufted vetch, cow vetch, bird vetch, blue vetch, boreal vetch), is a species of vetch native to Europe and Asia. It often occurs in disturbed habitats, including old-fields and roadside ditches.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["tufted vetch"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Vicia cracca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11554,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eriogonum trichopes, commonly known as little desert trumpet, is a drought-tolerant plant native to arid regions. Subsequent watering should be infrequent, only to prevent prolonged drought stress. In most climates, this means watering approximately once every few weeks. Ensure that the soil is well-draining to keep roots healthy in natural rainfall and supplemental watering cycles."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eriogonum trichopes thrives in full sun environments and needs a lot of light to maintain its growth and flowering. Avoid shaded areas, as insufficient sunlight can hinder the blooming process and reduce overall plant vitality. In climates with extreme heat, providing some afternoon shade may help prevent scorching, although this plant generally tolerates high temperatures and sun exposure well."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eriogonum trichopes should be minimal, as this plant naturally maintains an attractive shape while spilling or covering the ground. Pruning is mostly necessary to remove any dead or damaged stems, which encourages healthier growth and can be done in early spring. Light trimming may also be implemented to control its spread if it encroaches on other areas. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of disease. If the plant becomes too leggy or sparse, a more significant prune can rejuvenate its growth, but should be done carefully to avoid stressing the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Little Desert Trumpet","description":"Eriogonum trichopes is a species of wild buckwheat known by the common name little desert trumpet. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. It's best to use room temperature water and allow the excess to drain away to prevent waterlogged roots. During the growing season, you may need to water more frequently, while in the dormant winter months, you can cut back on watering. If the leaves start to drop, it may be a sign of underwatering or overwatering, so adjust accordingly until you find the right balance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus microcarpa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sunlight but avoid intense midday sun as it may scorch the leaves. If indoors, place it near a window where it can receive filtered light. This plant can adapt to lower light conditions, but growth may slow, and leaf drop may occur. If you notice leaves turning yellow or dropping off, consider relocating your Ficus microcarpa to a brighter spot to ensure it gets sufficient light to maintain its health and vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Ficus microcarpa to maintain its shape and size, preferably in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to promote healthy growth. Be cautious not to prune too heavily, as this can stress the plant. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, and consider wearing gloves as the sap can be irritating to skin. Pruning not only helps keep the plant tidy but also encourages a more full and bushy appearance by stimulating new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese banyan","description":"Ficus microcarpa, also known as Chinese banyan, Malayan banyan, Taiwan banyan, Indian laurel, curtain fig, or gajumaru (ガジュマル), is a tree native in the range from China through Nepal, Bhutan, Sikkim, India, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, the Malay Archipelago, New Guinea, Australia, the Ryukyu Islands, and New Caledonia. It is widely planted as a shade tree and frequently misidentified as F. retusa or as F. nitida (F. benjamina).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["Chinese banyan"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot","Nematodes","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Air Layering Propagation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ficus microcarpa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11158,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Grimmia pulvinata, commonly known as grey-cushioned grimmia, is a type of moss that requires minimal watering, particularly if it is grown in its natural outdoor environment. When cultivated indoors or in drier climates, watering should be done sparingly, ensuring that the soil or substrate remains just moist, not soggy. In indoor settings, artificial grow lights can also be an effective option to provide adequate lighting. Ensuring the moss is not in direct sun for extended periods will help maintain its vibrant and healthy appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Grimmia pulvinata is generally minimal due to its small, compact, and slow-growing nature. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10755,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus radiata, commonly known as Monterey pine, typically requires moderate watering. The tree is quite drought-tolerant once established but prefers consistent moisture in the soil, especially during its initial growth phase or in particularly dry spells. Water deeply to ensure moisture reaches the root zones, but allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. During extreme heat or dry periods, increase watering frequency. Ensure good drainage to avoid waterlogging, as this can be detrimental to pine health. Regular rainfall usually suffices for mature, established specimens in suitable climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus radiata thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. While it can tolerate a variety of light conditions, including partial shade, full sun exposure is crucial for vigorous growth and development, as it supports proper photosynthesis and reduces the likelihood of fungal diseases. Ensure your planting location receives ample sunlight throughout the day, although in regions with very intense summer heat, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent stress. Always consider the local climate when planning the sun exposure regimen."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pinus radiata is generally minimal, but it is essential for maintaining shape and removing any dead or diseased branches. The ideal time for pruning is late winter to early spring before new growth begins. For young trees, formative pruning can help develop a strong structure, while mature pines may require thinning to improve air circulation through the canopy. Avoid cutting back to bare wood, as this can inhibit regrowth. Regularly inspect for and remove cross branches or damaged limbs to maintain a healthy tree and aesthetic appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Monterey pine","description":"Pinus radiata, family Pinaceae, the Monterey pine, insignis pine or radiata pine, is a species of pine native to the Central Coast of California and Mexico (Guadalupe Island and Cedros island).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Mexico"],"other_name":["Monterey pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pine Pitch Canker","Bark Beetles"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pinus radiata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11460,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Artemisia dracunculus, commonly known as tarragon, prefers to be watered moderately. The plant thrives with a balance between dry and moist soil conditions. It is recommended to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot, as tarragon does not like to sit in waterlogged soil. During active growth in the spring and summer, water the plant more frequently, ensuring the top inch of soil is dry before the next watering. In cooler months, reduce watering to avoid overhydration. Always ensure adequate drainage to maintain optimal soil moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tarragon prefers full sunlight exposure for optimal growth. Aim to provide Artemisia dracunculus with at least 6–8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate some partial shade, especially in areas with very hot summers, prolonged shade will result in leggy growth and diminished flavor in the leaves. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window to ensure it gets adequate light. For outdoor cultivation, select a sunny spot that receives abundant light throughout the day to meet the plant's energetic needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Artemisia dracunculus is essential to encourage bushier growth and prolong the plant's lifespan. Regularly snip off flowers as they appear in order to prevent the plant from going to seed, which can slow growth. During the growing season, lightly prune to shape and remove any straggly stems. A more significant prune should be done in late winter or early spring, trimming the entire plant back by about one-third to promote vigorous new growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize stress and prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Tarragon","description":"Tarragon (Artemisia dracunculus), also known as estragon, is a species of perennial herb in the sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10256,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus contorta, commonly known as lodgepole pine, typically thrives in a wide range of soil conditions, from dry to moist but well-drained soils. When watering this conifer, it's crucial to avoid waterlogged conditions, which can lead to root rot. During the establishment period, water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. Once established, the tree is drought-tolerant and usually only requires supplemental watering during prolonged dry spells. Be mindful of the soil type; sandy soils will need more frequent watering, whereas clay soils may retain moisture longer."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus contorta thrives in full sun and should ideally receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and resin production occur with more sun exposure. Inadequate sunlight can lead to slower growth rates and less foliage density. If planting in an area that receives shade, ensure it is only partial and that the tree receives ample sunlight for the majority of the day. The tree is naturally adapted to open environments where sunlight is abundant, making full sun locations ideal for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pinus contorta should be done primarily to remove dead, diseased, or damaged branches. It's generally best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the tree and lead to poor health. Focus on maintaining the tree's natural shape by selectively removing branches that either overlap or grow towards the center of the crown. Always use sharp, sterilized tools to minimize damage and prevent the spread of disease. Regularly inspect the tree for signs of damage or disease that may require careful pruning intervention."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"lodgepole pine","description":"Pinus contorta, with the common names lodgepole pine and shore pine, and also known as twisted pine, and contorta pine, is a common tree in western North America. It is common near the ocean shore and in dry montane forests to the subalpine, but is rare in lowland rain forests. Like all pines (member species of the genus Pinus), it is an evergreen conifer.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["lodgepole pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus contorta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11555,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rumex hymenosepalus, commonly known as Canaigre or Wild Rhubarb, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. It is important to avoid overwatering as the plant thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid conditions. During the growth period, occasional deep watering is beneficial, especially in prolonged dry spells. However, ensure that the soil dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the dormant period, reduce watering significantly, as the plant survives well in dry soil conditions, consistent with its native habitat in arid and semi-arid regions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rumex hymenosepalus thrives in full sun conditions, akin to its native habitat in desert and arid regions. Providing at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily is ideal for its growth and development. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in extremely hot climates, too much shade may result in reduced vigor and fewer blooms. Planting it in a sunny spot ensures that it receives the necessary light to perform photosynthesis efficiently, promoting vigorous growth. However, in regions with extremely strong sunlight or intense midday heat, providing some afternoon shade can prevent dehydration and leaf scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rumex hymenosepalus is generally minimal since it is a hardy perennial. However, removing any dead or damaged leaves can promote healthier growth and improve appearance. If the plant becomes too unruly or dense, it can be trimmed back to maintain its size within the garden space. Pruning should ideally be carried out after the plant has finished flowering to prevent disrupting its natural growth cycle. Additionally, cutting back flower stalks once they fade can help direct the plant's energy towards strengthening its root system and encourage more robust foliage development in the next season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Canaigre Dock","description":"Rumex hymenosepalus, commonly known as canaigre, canaigre dock, ganagra, wild rhubarb, Arizona dock, and tanner's dock, is a perennial flowering plant which is native to the western United States and northern Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Canaigre Dock"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rumex hymenosepalus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Additionally, pruning may be required to control the plant's size and shape, especially if it's being grown in a confined space or container."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Zulu Giant","description":"Stapelia gigantea is a species of flowering plant in the family Apocynaceae, native to south eastern Africa. Water regularly to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during the active growing season in spring and summer. If grown in a container, check the soil frequently and water when the top 1-2 cm feels dry. Avoid letting the plant sit in standing water for extended periods to prevent root rot, although brief water immersion is tolerated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calla palustris thrives in partial to full shade environments but can tolerate some early morning or late afternoon sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially during midday, can be too intense and may scorch the leaves, particularly in hotter climates. Ideally, plant it in a location with dappled sunlight or where it receives filtered light. In indoor settings, place it near a north-facing window or under shade-loving plant lights. If grown near a water feature, the surrounding humidity and reflected light will help support its growth without the risk of excessive direct exposure to the sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calla palustris involves removing any dead or yellowing leaves throughout the growing season to maintain plant health and appearance. At the end of the flowering season, it's beneficial to cut back the flower stalks that have finished blooming to encourage the plant to focus energy on root development. Overall, minimal pruning is required, ensuring the plant retains enough foliage for photosynthesis while keeping it neat. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to avoid damaging the plant. If the plant becomes too bushy, slight trimming can help in maintaining shape and size."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"marsh calla","description":"Calla (bog arum, marsh calla, wild calla, squaw claw, and water-arum) is a genus of flowering plant in the family Araceae, containing the single species Calla palustris. Always adjust watering habits based on your local climate and changing weather conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hedychium gardnerianum thrives in partial to full sun conditions. Ideally, provide morning sun and afternoon shade to mimic its natural tropical environment. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window but protected from direct sunlight, which can scorch the leaves. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light will promote healthy growth and vibrant blooms, while too little light can cause leggy growth and reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kahili ginger involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth. After the flowering period, cut back the flower stalks to the base to maintain a tidy appearance and direct energy back to the plant. Regular maintenance will help the plant thrive and display its lush foliage and fragrant blooms effectively."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Kahili ginger","description":"Hedychium gardnerianum (Kahili ginger, Kahila garland-lily, or ginger lily (Aust.)) is a plant native to the Himalayas in India, Nepal, and Bhutan. It grows to 8 ft (2.4 m) tall with long, bright green leaves clasping the tall stems. The very fragrant pale yellow and red flowers are held in dense spikes above the foliage. They appear towards the end of summer.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Himalayas"],"other_name":["Kahili ginger"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Rhizome division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hedychium gardnerianum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rich","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11049,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viola tricolor, commonly known as wild pansy, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. During its growing season, water regularly to maintain the soil's moisture, especially in hot and dry periods. However, make sure the soil drains well to prevent water accumulation, which can lead to root rot. During cooler weather or when the plant is dormant, reduce watering frequency. It's important to monitor the soil moisture by feeling the top layer; if it feels dry to the touch, it's time to water. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases, opting for ground-level watering instead."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola tricolor thrives in locations that receive full sun to partial shade. Ideally, aim for at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes healthy growth and vibrant blooms. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from wilting or becoming scorched. The plant is quite adaptable and can tolerate less light, but this might result in fewer flowers. If grown indoors, place the viola near a bright window with several hours of sunlight. Adjust its location seasonally to ensure it receives adequate light year-round."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola tricolor involves regular deadheading to encourage blooming and prevent the plant from going to seed too quickly. Remove spent flowers by pinching or cutting the stem just above the nearest leaf. This practice not only extends the flowering period but also promotes bushier growth. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, you can trim it back by up to one-third to maintain a compact shape. In late fall, cut the plant back to tidy its appearance and prepare it for the dormant season. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and minimize the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wild Pansy","description":"Viola tricolor, also known as Johnny Jump up (though this name is also applied to similar species such as the yellow pansy), heartsease, heart's ease, heart's delight, tickle-my-fancy, Jack-jump-up-and-kiss-me, come-and-cuddle-me, three faces in a hood, or love-in-idleness, is a common European wild flower, growing as an annual or short-lived perennial.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Wild Pansy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Viola tricolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In their natural habitat, they thrive best with natural rainfall, and additional watering might only be necessary in periods of prolonged drought."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alliaria petiolata thrives in part shade to full shade environments, which aligns with its native habit of growing under tree canopies and forest understories. Too much direct sunlight, especially in hotter climates, could stress the plant, leading to wilting or stunted growth. Thus, providing filtered light or placing it in naturally shaded sections will yield the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Alliaria petiolata is mostly about controlling its spread, as it is an invasive species in many areas. All plant parts should be disposed of responsibly, as seeds can remain viable in the soil for several years. While it doesn't require shaping or aesthetic pruning, management trimming will help prevent it from dominating native plants."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"garlic mustard","description":"Alliaria petiolata is a biennial flowering plant in the Mustard family, Brassicaceae. During its first growing season, it requires regular watering to help establish its root system. In hot, dry climates, it may need additional watering periods, but avoid waterlogging as this can lead to root rot. It's best to allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions during the hotter months, while significantly reducing watering in the cooler, wetter months of fall and winter."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cercis occidentalis thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ensure the plant site provides enough space for it to receive adequate sunlight throughout the day while considering nearby structures or trees that might cast prolonged shadows."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cercis occidentalis should be done from late fall to early winter when the plant is dormant. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stunt its growth and affect blooming. Annual light pruning improves air circulation and sunlight penetration, promoting a healthy and attractive tree."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Western Redbud","description":"Cercis occidentalis, the western redbud or California redbud (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12046,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Alcea rosea, commonly known as hollyhock, prefers well-drained soil and benefits from regular watering to maintain evenly moist soil, especially during dry spells. However, be cautious not to overwater, as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. A good practice is to water deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Early morning is the best time to water to allow any excess moisture on the leaves to evaporate, minimizing the risk of fungal diseases. Mulching around the base can help conserve moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alcea rosea thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. Planting hollyhocks in a location where they receive morning sunlight is ideal, as it helps dry the dew on leaves and reduces the risk of rust disease. In regions with extremely hot afternoons, some light afternoon shade might prevent wilting, though these plants generally tolerate heat well. Inadequate sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so ensure they have sufficient exposure for a robust display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Alcea rosea involves cutting back spent flowers to encourage more blooms and maintain plant health. After the flowers have faded, snip off the flower stalks down to the first set of leaves. This not only tidies up the plant but also redirects energy to other parts, potentially resulting in more flowering. At the end of the growing season, cut the entire plant down to near ground level to tidy up your garden and reduce the risk of diseases overwintering in the remnants. Removing dead or damaged leaves throughout the season can also help maintain plant vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Hollyhock","description":"Alcea rosea (common hollyhock) is an ornamental plant in the Malvaceae family. It was imported into Europe from southwestern China during, or possibly before, the 15th century. William Turner, a herbalist of the time, gave it the name \"holyoke\" from which the English name derives.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Asia","Europe"],"other_name":["Hollyhock"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Alcea rosea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid deep shade as it can hinder flowering. If necessary, you can perform harder pruning to reshape the plant or control its size, but avoid cutting into mature wood as it may not regrow. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts at desired points above leaf nodes or branching stems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Rhododendron","description":"Rhododendron ponticum, called common rhododendron or pontic rhododendron, is a species of Rhododendron native to southern Europe and southwest Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["Common Rhododendron"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron ponticum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogged conditions to prevent fungal rot. Observing natural environments where this and similar fungi grow, such as damp, decaying wood, can offer clues for mimicking their natural watering needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypholoma fasciculare, or Sulphur Tuft, typically grows in shaded and damp environments such as forest floors. Avoid direct sunlight, as it could dry out the substrate or container holding the fungus, impacting its growth. Instead, mimic the dappled or diffuse light conditions found under forest canopies, allowing this species to thrive in naturally subdued lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning considerations are not applicable to Hypholoma fasciculare as it is a fungus rather than a plant. Fungi like Sulphur Tuft do not require pruning like traditional plants. However, in controlling its spread in natural or educational contexts, ensuring that old, decaying wood is cleared might limit its growth, as it primarily decomposes such materials. If you notice unwanted growth on your premises, it may be best to remove the substrate material or relocate the fungus to a controlled environment for observation rather than altering the fungus itself."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"Sulphur Tuft","description":"Hypholoma fasciculare, commonly known as the sulphur tuft, sulfur tuft or clustered woodlover, is a common woodland mushroom, often in evidence when hardly any other mushrooms are to be found. Consistent sunlight helps maintain its dense, compact form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Berberis pinnata annually to maintain shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches. Then, thin out crowded areas to improve airflow and light penetration within the shrub. You can also shape the plant by cutting back overly long branches. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts just above a leaf node. Be cautious of the plant's thorns while pruning, and wear gloves to protect your hands."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California barberry","description":"Mahonia pinnata (syn. This maintenance ensures the fungus can mature fully and healthily. It's important to adjust your watering schedule based on the weather and soil conditions, ensuring the tree receives adequate moisture without becoming waterlogged."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juglans hindsii thrives best in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. Ensure that the planting location is free from overshadowing by larger structures or trees to provide adequate light. Proper sunlight also helps keep the tree healthy by reducing the risk of diseases that can thrive in shaded, damp conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juglans hindsii is essential to maintain a healthy and structurally sound tree. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11051,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Veronica arvensis, commonly known as wall speedwell, prefers moderately moist soil conditions. However, ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can be detrimental to its roots. Once established, this plant can tolerate some drought, but for optimal growth, a consistent watering routine is beneficial. During periods of rainfall, additional watering might not be necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Veronica arvensis thrives in full sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade, particularly in hotter climates. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure optimal growth and flowering. Carefully select its growing site, balancing between adequate light and protection from extreme conditions for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Veronica arvensis is relatively straightforward. This plant does not require regular pruning, but you can trim it to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can help promote further blooming and prevent the plant from self-seeding too excessively, as it can spread quickly if left unchecked. If the plant becomes too leggy or untidy, trim back the stems in spring or summer. Be sure to remove any dead or damaged foliage to promote healthier growth and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"corn speedwell","description":"Veronica arvensis (common names: wall speedwell,:592 corn speedwell, common speedwell, rock speedwell,), Field speedwell is an annual flowering plant in the plantain family Plantaginaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10548,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus resinosa, commonly known as Red Pine, is a drought-tolerant species once established. Young trees need regular watering during their first few years to ensure proper root development, especially in hot or dry periods. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot. Mature trees usually do not require supplemental watering unless in times of severe drought. It is crucial to ensure good drainage in their planting location to prevent waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus resinosa thrives in full sunlight conditions, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. It prefers open spaces and is well-suited for planting in forest edges, clearings, or as a specimen tree in landscapes. While it can tolerate partial shade during its early development, full sun exposure helps promote dense growth and a well-shaped canopy. Ensure the site has minimal shading for optimal health and growth, keeping away competing species that might overshadow it."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus resinosa is mainly done to remove dead or diseased branches or to shape the tree for aesthetic purposes. The best time to prune Red Pine is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, and avoid cutting into the trunk. Remove no more than one-third of the total branch structure in a single season to avoid stressing the tree. Pruning can also help increase air circulation within the canopy, reducing disease risk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red pine","description":"Pinus resinosa, known as red pine or Norway pine, is a pine native to North America. It occurs from Newfoundland west to Manitoba, and south to Pennsylvania, with several smaller, disjunct populations occurring in the Appalachian Mountains in Virginia and West Virginia, as well as a few small pockets in extreme northern New Jersey and northern Illinois.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["red pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pine shoot beetle","Sawflies","Zimmerman pine moth","Adelgids","Pine looper caterpillar","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus resinosa"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11349,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polypodium californicum, also known as the California polypody, thrives in moist but well-drained soil. It prefers consistent moisture levels, particularly during its active growing period in fall and winter. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to avoid waterlogging the roots. During the summer dormancy period, reduce watering significantly, as the plant naturally withstands drier conditions during this time. Ensure the plant is not sitting in water as it can lead to root rot. Adjust watering frequency depending on the local climate and indoor humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polypodium californicum prefers a semi-shaded environment, thriving in dappled sunlight or bright, indirect light. Natural habitats include shaded woodland areas, so replicating similar conditions will benefit the plant. Direct sunlight can cause the fronds to scorch, so it’s best placed away from intense afternoon sun. If growing indoors, an east or north-facing window is ideal, providing gentle, filtered light throughout the day. In a garden setting, it does well under the canopy of larger trees or shrubs. Ensure that the plant receives adequate light to maintain its vibrant frond color and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polypodium californicum is a straightforward task. This fern primarily requires the removal of dead or damaged fronds to maintain its aesthetic appeal and encourage healthy new growth. Trim back any browning or dried fronds at their base, especially at the end of its active cycle, during the late winter. Avoid excessive pruning of healthy fronds, as this can stress the plant. Clearing out dead foliage also helps enhance air circulation and reduces the risk of pest infestations. Regular maintenance pruning keeps the fern looking tidy and can promote a more vigorous growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Polypody","description":"Polypodium californicum is a species of fern known by the common name California polypody.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["California Polypody"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores","Rhizome Division"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Polypodium californicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water young trees deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to encourage deep root growth. Mature piñon pines generally only need supplemental watering during extended dry periods. Be cautious not to overwater as this can lead to root rot and other moisture-related issues. In well-draining soil, ensure that each watering is thorough, reaching several inches of depth to promote healthy root development and resilience."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus edulis thrives in full sun environments. The piñon pine is adapted to thrive in open areas with ample sunlight, which is essential for its growth and production of cones. Ensure the planting site is unobstructed by larger trees or structures that could block sunlight. Removing more than 25% of the tree's foliage at one time is not recommended as it can weaken the plant and make it vulnerable to pests and diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Colorado Pinyon","description":"Pinus edulis, the Colorado pinyon, two-needle piñon, pinyon pine, or simply piñon, is a pine in the pinyon pine group whose ancestor was a member of the Madro-Tertiary Geoflora (a group of drought resistant trees) and is native to the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Colorado Pinyon"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus edulis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, you may want to trim back any leggy or overgrown stems to maintain its compact form and encourage denser growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning tools to make cuts just above a leaf node or where the stem branches out. Removing dead or damaged leaves regularly can also help keep the plant healthy. Pruning should ideally be done during the growing season, from spring to early summer, to allow the plant to recover quickly."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mossy Stonecrop","description":"Crassula tillaea is a succulent plant known by its common names mossy stonecrop and moss pygmyweed. Ensure it has space to expand, as it will develop a large canopy over time."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juglans nigra is essential for maintaining its structure and health. Prune during the dormant season, ideally late fall to early winter, to minimize sap loss and reduce the risk of disease spread. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote airflow and light penetration. Thin out crowded areas and shape the tree to a balanced form. Avoid heavy pruning in one season; instead, spread pruning over several years to lessen stress on the tree. Regularly check for crossing branches and remove them to prevent damage as they grow."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern black walnut","description":"Juglans nigra, the eastern black walnut, is a species of deciduous tree in the walnut family, Juglandaceae, native to eastern North America. Wild trees in the upper Ottawa Valley may be an isolated native population or may have derived from planted trees.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["eastern black walnut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Walnut Husk Fly","Aphids","Borers"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Juglans nigra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The plant's ability to thrive in shaded areas helps reduce evaporation, leading to less frequent watering needs compared to plants in full sun."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galium odoratum thrives in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for woodland gardens or shaded borders. This shade tolerance makes it well-suited for growing under trees or in shadowed areas where other plants might struggle. You can also trim back any dead or damaged foliage to keep the plant healthy. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10550,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus strobus, or eastern white pine, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering once established. In its early stages or if planted in a particularly dry season, water the pine deeply once a week. Ensure the soil is moist but not waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Once the tree matures, natural rainfall is usually sufficient to meet its water needs, unless there is an extended period of drought. Always allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to avoid overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus strobus thrives best in full sun, ideally receiving at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but optimum growth occurs with more sunlight exposure. Trees grown in shady environments may appear leggy or sparse as they stretch out for more light. Full sunlight promotes a dense, sturdy growth habit, contributing to the tree's longevity and health. When planting, ensure the site has enough sun exposure, and avoid overly shaded areas to prevent inadequate development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus strobus should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove only the dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain tree health. Pinching or cutting back new growth can control size and form, but be cautious not to over-prune, as this pine can look lopsided if too much is removed. Due to their natural shape, these trees require minimal pruning once established, primarily to ensure the tree's structural integrity and remove hazardous branches."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern white pine","description":"Pinus strobus, commonly denominated the eastern white pine, northern white pine, white pine, Weymouth pine (British), and soft pine is a large pine native to eastern North America. It occurs from Newfoundland, Canada west through the Great Lakes region to southeastern Manitoba and Minnesota, United States, and south along the Appalachian Mountains and upper Piedmont to northernmost Georgia and perhaps very rarely in some of the higher elevations in northeastern Alabama.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["eastern white pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Sawfly"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pinus strobus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When grown in gardens, it should be watered regularly to mimic its natural habitat, especially during dry spells. Ensure that the plant is not left to dry out completely, as this could hinder its growth and overall health. Ensuring the plant is not exposed to harsh afternoon sun can help maintain its lush, green appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex pseudocyperus involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and health. Regularly tidying up the plant encourages robust and healthy growth throughout the season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cyperus Sedge","description":"Carex pseudocyperus is a species of flowering plant in the sedge family known by the common name cyperus sedge or hop sedge. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11748,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lilium humboldtii, commonly known as Humboldt's lily, requires well-drained soil and should be watered deeply but infrequently. It is vital to allow the topsoil to dry out moderately between waterings to prevent root rot. Overwatering is more damaging than occasional underwatering. During its growing period in spring and early summer, increase the frequency of watering, but ensure that the soil remains not overly saturated. Taper off watering as the plant enters dormancy in late summer. Using mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering needed."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Humboldt's lily thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, especially morning sun. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from the intense midday sun which can scorch the leaves. Site this lily in a location where it can receive reliable sunlight, but ensure it's shielded from extreme heat. If growing in an area with intense sun, consider planting it alongside taller plants or structures that can provide dappled sunlight or sufficient shade during the hottest part of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lilium humboldtii involves cutting back the stem only after the foliage has completely yellowed and died back in the fall. This dying foliage process provides the bulb with nutrients for the next blooming cycle. Removing the dead stalks close to ground level after the plant has naturally died back helps maintain plant health and appearance. Additionally, any diseased or damaged leaves should be pruned throughout the blooming season to prevent the spread of disease and encourage healthy growth, taking care not to remove too many leaves at once."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Humboldt's Lily","description":"Lilium humboldtii (Humboldt's lily) is a species of lily native to the US state of California and the Mexican state of Baja California. It is named after naturalist and explorer Alexander von Humboldt. It is native to the South High Cascade Range, High Sierra Nevada, south Outer South Coast Ranges, and the Santa Monica Mountains and others in Southern California, growing at elevations from 600 metres (2,000 ft) to 1,200 metres (3,900 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Mexico"],"other_name":["Humboldt's Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lilium humboldtii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

St. John's Wort is somewhat drought-tolerant, so it's better to err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. Regular pruning helps prevent leggy growth and keeps the plant looking tidy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common St. John's Wort","description":"Hypericum perforatum, known as perforate St John's-wort, common Saint John's wort and St John's wort, is a flowering plant in the family Hypericaceae. Therefore, Hypericum perforatum is sometimes called \"common St John's wort\" or \"perforate St John's wort\" to differentiate it. Ensure they have good light exposure to promote dense, leafy growth; however, partial afternoon shade can be beneficial in particularly hot regions to protect them from heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Brassica oleracea involves removing yellowing or damaged leaves regularly to ensure healthy growth and prevent disease. It's also helpful to monitor for and remove any forming seed heads as many varieties, like certain kales, can prematurely bolt (go to seed), especially in warmer climates. Regular pruning encourages better airflow and light penetration, helping to avoid pests and diseases. Ensure to disinfect tools between uses to prevent the spread of pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cabbage, broccoli, and allies","description":"Brassica oleracea is a plant species that includes many common foods as cultivars, including cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower, kale, Brussels sprouts, collard greens, Savoy cabbage, kohlrabi, and gai lan.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["cabbage, broccoli, and allies"],"pest_susceptibility":["Cabbageworm","Aphids","Flea Beetles"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Brassica oleracea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with intense afternoon sun, providing some shade during these hours can help prevent leaf scorch and maintain optimal health. Ideally, morning sun and afternoon shade will support vibrant flowering and healthy foliage growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geum rivale involves deadheading spent flowers and cutting back any damaged or dead foliage to promote healthy growth and prolong the flowering period. You should deadhead the plant regularly during its blooming season to encourage more blooms and prevent it from self-seeding aggressively. In late autumn, trim back the foliage to tidy up the plant for winter, but avoid cutting too close to the ground. Pruning helps maintain a compact form and can rejuvenate the plant for the following year’s growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Water Avens","description":"Geum rivale, the water avens, is a flowering plant of the family Rosaceae. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so ensure the soil dries out between watering sessions, particularly in cooler ecosystems or during dormant winter months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heteromeles arbutifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive full morning sun to catalyze berry production and ensure healthy growth. While it can tolerate some shade, too much shade might hinder its flowering and fruiting capabilities. For optimal performance in coastal areas and mild climates, provide it with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hot inland regions, a location with some afternoon shade can protect it from excessive heat and help maintain moisture, consequently improving its longevity and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heteromeles arbutifolia is best done in late winter to early spring before new growth emerges. Light pruning can help maintain a desirable shape and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood. Avoid heavy pruning as this can detrimentally affect the plant's health and reduce berry production. Focus on removing any crossing branches and old stems to improve air circulation within the plant. Toyon benefits from thinning to allow light penetration, which enhances overall growth and berry production. Careful, minimal pruning will encourage a healthy, berry-laden growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Toyon","description":"Heteromeles arbutifolia (/ˌhɛtɪroʊˈmiːliːz ɑːrˌbjuːtɪˈfoʊliə/; more commonly /ˌhɛtəˈrɒməliːz/ by Californian botanists), commonly known as toyon, is a common perennial shrub native to extreme southwest Oregon, California, Baja California, and British Columbia.
